results.title: Newton, Einstein and gravity
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
Aristotle and Galileo were pioneers in the study of motion. From the Greek concept of natural and violent motion, came Galileo’s ideas about impetus and inertia. Scientists like Keppler further developed these ideas. However, Issac Newton, with his Laws on Motion and Universal Gravitation, altered the study of physics and astronomy forever. Newton was able to mathematically work out the effects of gravity, however he was unable to identify a cause. It was Albert Einstein with his theories of Relativity and Curved Space/Time dimensions which changed the way scientists perceived the Laws of Gravity and space travel. This episode examines these pioneers and their ideas.

results.title: The Origin of modern astronomy
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
The Greeks considered the Earth to be the centre of the universe. Ptolemy’s model of the universe lasted until Copernicus began to postulate that it was the Earth which moved around the sun. Due to his allegiance to the Church, Copernicus did not pursue his theories, but Galileo, was able, with the invention of the telescope, to support the Copernican model of the universe. His ideas were considered heretical by the Counter-Reformation Church, however they sowed the seeds for future observation and theories. The work of Kepler followed, and it is this work, supporting Copernicus and Galileo which bridged the gap between ancient and modern astronomy.

results.title: Cycles of the sky
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
This episode examines the influence that the Moon and its orbit has on the earth and the phenomena of lunar and solar eclipses. By observing the phases of the moon, early astronomers were able to divide the calendar into months, and the Earth’s rotation around the sun was responsible for the measurement of time into seasons. The Moon’s two types of orbit, Siberial and Sinotic are explained. Outlines how the Moon affects tides by the gravitational pull it exerts. Although readily explained scientifically, the solar and lunar eclipses still fascinate astronomers, professional and amateur alike, with their beauty and wonder.

results.title: The Sky
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
Ancient skywatchers observed the passing phases of the moon and movements of the sun, planets and stars to determine direction, time and the seasonal cyclical rhythms. Structures like Stonehenge were seasonal calendars based on astronomical observations and although different cultures saw formations of stars differently, the use of constellations to determine directions and seasons was commonplace. The Greeks were the first race to apply mathematical principles to their astronomical observations.

results.title: The Scale of the cosmos
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coastline Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
Questions about our universe have intrigued the human race since time began. What is the universe made of? How did it come to be? How big is it? Even though astronomers concern themselves with these questions on a scientific level, what remains is a sense of wonder. Even using relative comparisons, the vastness of the universe is still a mystery. Stars, supernova, pulsars and black holes are just some of the phenomenon used to determine the scale of the universe.

results.title: The Adventures of Tintin

results.title: Tintin in Tibet
results.creator_credit: Stephane Bernasconi, Foundation Herge, Nelvana and Ellipse
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Adventures of Tintin”.
When Tintin reads a newspaper report of a Nepalese air disaster, little does he know that his vacation is about to take him to the Himalayas and adventure! Tintin’s dear friend Chang is aboard the crashed plane and although there are no reported survivors, Tintin is sure that Chang is alive. With Captain Haddock’s help they battle blizzards and the Yeti to find Chang.

results.title: The Blue lotus
results.creator_credit: Stephane Bernasconi, Robert Rea, Nelvana and Ellipse
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Adventures of Tintin”.
In the midst of a battle with smugglers, Tintin arrives in China, where he rescues a drowning Chang, a real-life friend of Herge who developed “The Adventures of Tintin”. Tintin must use all his courage, daring and intelligence to outsmart the traps of his enemies.
